an6.54:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
an6.54:1.2: Now at that time Venerable Dhammika was a resident in all seven monasteries of his native land.
an6.54:1.3: There he abused visiting mendicants; he insulted, harmed, attacked, and harassed them.
an6.54:1.4: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way did not stay. They left, abandoning the monastery.
an6.54:2.1: Then the local lay followers thought to themselves,
an6.54:2.2: “We have supplied the mendicant Saṅgha with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
an6.54:2.3: But the visiting mendicants don’t stay. They leave, abandoning the monastery.
an6.54:2.4: What is the cause, what is the reason for this?”
an6.54:2.5: Then the local lay followers thought to themselves,
an6.54:2.6: “This Venerable Dhammika abuses visiting mendicants; he insults, harms, attacks, and harasses them.
an6.54:2.7: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way do not stay. They leave, abandoning the monastery.
an6.54:2.8: Why don’t we banish Venerable Dhammika?”

an6.54:7.1: Then Venerable Dhammika took his bowl and robe and set out for Rājagaha.
an6.54:7.2: Eventually he came to Rājagaha and the Vulture’s Peak. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
an6.54:7.3: “So, Brahmin Dhammika, where have you come from?”
an6.54:7.4: “Sir, I’ve been banished by the local lay followers from all seven monasteries in my native land.”
an6.54:7.5: “Enough, Brahmin Dhammika, what’s that to you? Now that you’ve been banished from all of those places, you have come to me.
an6.54:8.1: Once upon a time, some sea-merchants set sail for the ocean deeps, taking with them a land-spotting bird.
an6.54:8.2: When their ship was out of sight of land, they released the bird.
an6.54:8.3: It flew right away to the east, the west, the north, the south, upwards, and in-between.
an6.54:8.4: If it saw land on any side, it went there and stayed.
an6.54:8.5: But if it saw no land on any side it returned to the ship.
an6.54:8.6: In the same way, now that you’ve been banished from all of those places, you have come to me.
an6.54:9.1: Once upon a time, King Koravya had a royal banyan tree with five trunks called ‘Well Planted’. It was shady and lovely.
an6.54:9.2: Its canopy spread over twelve leagues, while the network of roots spread for five leagues.
an6.54:9.3: Its fruits were as large as
an6.54:9.5: And they were as sweet as
an6.54:9.7: The king and harem made use of one trunk, the troops another, the people of town and country another, ascetics and brahmins another, and beasts and birds another.
an6.54:9.8: No-one guarded the fruit, yet no-one damaged another’s fruits.
an6.54:10.1: Then a certain person ate as much as he liked of the fruit, then broke off a branch and left.
an6.54:10.2: Then the deity haunting the royal banyan tree thought,
an6.54:10.4: How wicked this person is, to eat as much as they like, then break off a branch and leave! Why don’t I make sure that the royal banyan tree gives no fruit in future?’
an6.54:10.5: Then the royal banyan tree gave no more fruit.
an6.54:11.1: Then King Koravya went up to Sakka, lord of gods, and said to him,
an6.54:11.2: ‘Please good fellow, you should know that the royal banyan tree called Well Planted gives no fruit.’
an6.54:11.3: Then Sakka used his psychic powers to will that a violent storm come. And it felled and uprooted the royal banyan tree.
an6.54:11.4: Then the deity haunting the tree stood to one side, miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face.
an6.54:12.1: Then Sakka went up to that deity, and said,
an6.54:12.2: ‘Why, god, are you standing to one side, miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face?’
an6.54:12.3: ‘Because, my good fellow, a violent storm came and felled and uprooted my home.’
an6.54:12.4: ‘Well, did you stand by your tree’s duty when the storm came?’
an6.54:12.5: ‘But my good fellow, how does a tree stand by its duty?’
an6.54:12.6: ‘It’s when those who need the tree’s roots, bark, leaves, flowers, or fruit take what they need.
an6.54:12.7: Yet the deity is not displeased or upset because of this.
an6.54:12.8: This is how a tree stands by its duty.’
an6.54:12.9: ‘I was not standing by a tree’s duty when the storm came and felled and uprooted my home.’
an6.54:12.10: ‘God, if you were to stand by a tree’s duty, your home may be as it was before.’
an6.54:12.11: ‘I will stand by a tree’s duty! May my home be as it was before!’
an6.54:13.1: Then Sakka used his psychic power to will that a violent storm come. And it raised up that mighty banyan tree and the bark of the roots was healed.
an6.54:13.2: In the same way, Brahmin Dhammika, were you standing by an ascetic’s duty when the local lay followers banished you from all seven of the monasteries in your native land?”
an6.54:13.3: “But sir, how do I stand by an ascetic’s duty?”
an6.54:13.4: “When someone abuses, annoys, or argues with an ascetic, the ascetic doesn’t abuse, annoy, or argue back at them.
an6.54:13.5: That’s how an ascetic stands by an ascetic’s duty.”
an6.54:13.6: “I was not standing by an ascetic’s duty when the local lay followers banished me from all seven of the monasteries in my native land.”
an6.54:13.7: “Once upon a time, there was a teacher named Sunetta. He was a religious founder and was free of desire for sensual pleasures.
an6.54:13.8: He had many hundreds of disciples.
an6.54:13.9: He taught them the path to rebirth in the company of Divinity.
an6.54:13.10: Those lacking confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an6.54:13.11: Those full of confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
an6.54:14.1: Once upon a time there was a teacher named Mūgapakkha …
an6.54:18.1: Jotipāla. He was a religious founder and was free of desire for sensual pleasures.
an6.54:18.2: He had many hundreds of disciples.
an6.54:18.3: He taught them the way to rebirth in the company of Divinity.
an6.54:18.4: Those lacking confidence in Jotipāla were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an6.54:18.5: Those full of confidence in Jotipāla were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
an6.54:19.1: What do you think, Brahmin Dhammika?
an6.54:19.2: If someone with malicious intent were to abuse and insult these six teachers with their hundreds of followers, would they not brim with much wickedness?”
an6.54:19.5: But someone who abuses and insults a single individual accomplished in view with malicious intent brims even more with wickedness.
an6.54:19.7: Brahmin Dhammika, I say that any injury done by those outside of the Buddhist community does not compare with what is done to one’s own spiritual companions.
an6.54:19.8: So you should train like this:
an6.54:19.9: ‘We will have no malicious intent for those who we want to have as our spiritual companions.’
an6.54:19.10: That is how you should train.
